item.title: Survivors of the Deadly Hong Kong Fire Are in Limbo
item.description: Hong Kong, with some of the world’s highest housing costs and inequality, must now figure out how to help thousands of residents who lost friends, family and homes.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Theodora Yu and Joy Dong

media:content.media:description: Wang Fuk Court, a residential estate in the Tai Po district of Hong Kong, after a blaze damaged the complex late last month.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Dancing With the Babies Can Give Grown-Ups a Lesson
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 6, 2025.

item.title: China’s Mad at Japan, and Pop Stars Are Paying for It
item.description: Beijing is curbing Japanese movies, music and art as it seeks to punish Tokyo for its support of Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Hisako Ueno

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 6, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 6, 2025.

item.title: Easy Holiday Snack Recipes
item.description: The best way to start the celebration? Serving these unforgettable treats.
item.dc:creator: Yewande Komolafe

media:content.media:credit: Kelly Marshall for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Roscoe Betsill. Prop Stylist: Sarah Smart.

item.title: Brazil Has a Cachaça Cocktail for Every Season
item.description: If summer is for bottomless caipirinhas, winter is all about warming quentão. Here are recipes for both.
item.dc:creator: Rebekah Peppler

media:content.media:credit: Bobbi Lin for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Rebecca Jurkevich. Prop Stylist: Megan Hedgpeth.

item.title: Winter Quaffs
item.description: Marshal Herrmann’s quick-witted Saturday debut puzzle is quite quizzical.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:description: A water vole, transported by Pringles can, was introduced to a nature reserve in Gloucester, England, in 2008.

item.title: Man Accused of Setting Subway Rider on Fire Is Charged With Arson
item.description: The victim was sleeping on a train at Penn Station in Manhattan around 3 a.m. Monday when an 18-year-old man set him on fire, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker

media:content.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The man who was set on fire was taken to the hospital in critical condition, according to a criminal complaint from federal prosecutors.

item.title: Under RFK Jr., U.S. Vaccine Policy Arrives at a ‘Defining Moment’
item.description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. may be only beginning to put his stamp on American immunization policy.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, has methodically laid the groundwork to overhaul American vaccine policy.

item.title: Judge Rules Trump Exceeded Authority by Holding Deportees at Guantánamo
item.description: Judge Sparkle L. Sooknanan stopped short of ordering the shuttering of the detention operation. But a lawyer for the challengers said they would soon seek a closure order.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg

media:content.media:description: Deportees from El Paso being transported to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on a military cargo plane early this year.

item.title: How to Buy a World Cup Ticket
item.description: Want to acquire a FIFA World Cup ticket? There are some steps you should follow. Henry Bushnell, a senior soccer writer for The Athletic, details how.
item.dc:creator: The Athletic

item.title: Did Gen X Invent Indie Film?
item.description: The actors Claire Danes, Luis Guzmán and Omar Epps discuss the indie film era in this excerpt from a T Magazine documentary about how Generation X, the cohort once synonymous with slacking, came to leave such an indelible impression on the culture.
item.dc:creator: Megan Lovallo and Jamie Bradley

item.title: San Diego Agrees to Pay $30 Million to Family of Konoa Wilson, Teen Killed by Police
item.description: Konoa Wilson was 16 when he was fatally shot. The settlement, one of the largest in a police killing, surpasses the $27 million paid to the family of George Floyd.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango

item.title: Locro de Gallina (Chicken Soup With Squash, Green Plantains and Yuca)
item.description: Derived from a Quechua term for a hearty soup-stew hybrid, locro originated in the Andes mountain range but today encompasses a glut of South American soups that vary from country to country, and household to household.

item.title: Biden Slams Republicans for Using L.G.B.T.Q. Identity as ‘Political Football’
item.description: The former president defended his support for transgender rights, a stance that has provoked second-guessing among some Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon

media:content.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. received an award from the LGBTQ+ Victory Institute on Friday in Washington.

item.title: Trumpism After Trump? Here Are Three Realities.
item.description: “Trumpism without Trump is going to move in different directions because Trumpism was always a somewhat amorphous set of half-baked ideas,” Bret Stephens says.

item.title: How Charismatic Can a Moderate Politician Be?
item.description: “I think Americans — those who are not spending all their lives on social media — are so tired of the temperature of our political discourse,” Frank Bruni says on “The Opinions.” The solution? A “poetic and charismatic” centrist.

item.title: How Has Congestion Pricing Changed Your Year?
item.description: The tolling program, decades in the making, has shown signs of being effective after a rocky rollout.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hu and Stefanos Chen

item.title: Frank O. Gehry, Formidable Architect, Dies at 96
item.description: The innovative architect was known for his sculptural designs, including the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao and the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles. He passed away at his home in Santa Monica, Calif., on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

media:content.media:description: Frank Gehry in 2003, at a dedication ceremony for his Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles.

item.title: Running Out of Time, Republicans in Congress Still Lack a Health Plan
item.description: Top Republicans have said they want to produce a proposal in short order to counter Democrats pressing for an extension of health care subsidies. They have not gotten far.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

media:content.media:description: Senator Tim Scott at the Capitol earlier this year.

item.title: For Tekashi69, Drugs and Fight Add Up to Three More Months in Prison
item.description: The rapper, who was sentenced to two years in prison after testifying for the government at a gang trial, was ordered incarcerated for probation violations.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan

media:content.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tekashi69, whose legal name is Daniel Hernandez, rocketed to prominence as a rapper while cultivating an association with the Nine Trey Gangsta Bloods gang.

item.title: Justices to Review Trump’s Order Restricting Birthright Citizenship
item.description: Also, the celebrated architect Frank Gehry dies at 96. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Chi Ossé, NYC Councilman, Ends Primary Challenge to Rep. Hakeem Jeffries
item.description: Chi Ossé had hoped to ride the momentum of Zohran Mamdani to challenge Representative Hakeem Jeffries, but he failed to secure the backing of the Democratic Socialists of America.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Shane Goldmacher

media:content.media:description: Chi Ossé, 27, is a first-term councilman who has been sharply critical of Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the House Democratic leader, as “unfit to lead the fight against fascism.”

item.title: Robert B. Fiske Jr., First to Lead Whitewater Investigation, Dies at 94
item.description: He had overseen high-profile cases as a private lawyer and a U.S. attorney in New York when he was named to examine the role of Bill and Hillary Clinton in a failed development venture.
item.dc:creator: Joseph P. Fried and Clay Risen

media:content.media:description: Robert B. Fiske Jr. in March 1994, three months after being appointed independent counsel in the Whitewater matter.

item.title: Extreme Cold Will Persist in the Midwest and Northern Plains Into the Weekend
item.description: Saranac Lake, N.Y., in the Adirondacks was the coldest place in the United States on Friday, recording a low of minus 22 degrees.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff

item.title: Trump’s Security Strategy Focuses on Profit, Not Spreading Democracy
item.description: President Trump’s new National Security Strategy describes a country that is focused on doing business and reducing migration while avoiding passing judgment on authoritarians.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump at the White House last month. The National Security Strategy his administration released describes a world in which American interests are far narrower than how prior administrations — even in his first term — had portrayed them.

item.title: What to Know About New Orleans’s Immigrant Community Amid Trump Crackdown
item.description: The city, the latest to be targeted by the president in his deportation campaign, has a smaller foreign-born population than the national average, according to census data.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A sign outside a Latino-run business in Kenner, La., a suburb of New Orleans.

item.title: Chuck Kesey, Probiotic Yogurt Pioneer, Dies at 87
item.description: The younger brother of Ken Kesey, the novelist and counterculture luminary, he turned a defunct creamery into what is now Nancy’s Probiotic Foods.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Hamilton O. Smith, Who Made a Biotech Breakthrough, Is Dead at 94
item.description: A Nobel laureate, he identified an enzyme that cuts DNA, laying the groundwork for milestones in scientific research and medicine, like insulin.
item.dc:creator: Delthia Ricks

media:content.media:credit: Marty Katz for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Hamilton Smith in 2000. His work essentially handed scientists the power to isolate, analyze and manually move discrete sequences of DNA.

item.title: Frank Gehry, the Disrupter, Opened Their Imaginations
item.description: Architects, artists, clients and partners assess his life and impact over eight decades.
item.dc:creator: Sam Lubell

media:content.media:description: Frank Gehry in 1988 in front of his famed Santa Monica, Calif., house, its Dutch Colonial core wrapped with a combination of chain-link fencing, corrugated metal, and off-kilter windows and beams.

item.title: Muere Frank Gehry, titán de la arquitectura
item.description: Irrumpió en escena con una reforma de su casa del sur de California que llamó la atención, antes de pasar a diseñar algunos de los edificios más reconocibles del mundo.
item.dc:creator: Nicolai Ouroussoff

item.title: The Supreme Court, Once Wary of Partisan Gerrymandering, Goes All In
item.description: The court’s conservative majority said that Texas’ asserted political motives justified letting the state use voting maps meant to disadvantage Democrats in the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak

media:content.media:description: A map of Texas’ congressional districts during a hearing in Austin in August.

item.title: Man Who Swallowed Stolen Fabergé Egg Passes It Naturally, Police Say
item.description: The man ingested the egg locket at a jewelry store in New Zealand last week, according to the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

media:content.media:credit: New Zealand Police, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: “No medical intervention was required, and the pendant passed naturally,” the police said in a statement.

item.title: Linda McMahon’s School Visit, Sponsored by Conservatives, Draws Protest
item.description: The secretary of education is barnstorming the country, talking to schoolchildren about civics and promoting patriotism. Critics claim the lessons have been crafted by partisan and religious groups.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully

media:content.media:description: Linda McMahon, the secretary of education, kicked off a national series of talks to schoolchildren in New Jersey on Friday.

item.title: As Bongino Celebrates Arrest in Pipe Bomb Case, Others on the Right Remain Skeptical
item.description: Some activists have lashed out, in a reprise of the backlash over the unsuccessful effort by Trump appointees to shut down the Epstein investigation.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Dan Bongino, the F.B.I.’s deputy director, has alienated some inside the White House with his confrontational, self-promotional approach.

item.title: How D’Angelo Understood His Own Mortality
item.description: Wesley Morris invited his friend Alex Pappademas, a senior culture editor at GQ magazine, to his show to talk about mortality and D’Angelo’s final album, “Black Messiah.”
item.dc:creator: Cannonball With Wesley Morris

item.title: D’Angelo and the Brilliant Prescience of ‘Black Messiah’
item.description: Wesley Morris invited his friend Alex Pappademas, a senior culture editor at GQ magazine, to his show to talk about D’Angelo’s final album, “Black Messiah,” and why it’s so memorable.
item.dc:creator: Cannonball With Wesley Morris

item.title: Las discusiones de los ataques de Trump a embarcaciones, explicadas
item.description: La supervisión bipartidista del Congreso está en marcha, pero por ahora se enfoca en detalles concretos sobre un misil en lugar de en cuestiones legales más amplias.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:description: Las órdenes del Secretario de Defensa, Pete Hegseth, relativas al ataque letal del 2 de septiembre contra un barco en el Caribe están bajo escrutinio.

item.title: FIFA President Awards Trump With Soccer Body’s First Peace Prize
item.description: Not long after President Trump missed out on the Nobel Peace Prize, his friend and FIFA president, Gianni Infantino, had his organization establish its own.
item.dc:creator: McKinnon de Kuyper

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump, holding a replica of the men’s World Cup, with Gianni Infantino, the president of FIFA, in the Oval Office in August. Mr. Trump later asked to keep the trophy.

item.title: Erik Bulatov, Russian Painter Who Undermined Soviet Propaganda, Dies at 92
item.description: For years he lived a double life, secretly making anti-Communist paintings. He found fame in the late 1980s, once his work was shown outside the Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

media:content.media:description: Red Horizon by Erik Bulatov

item.title: A Look at What Lives Where Deep Sea Mining Would Happen
item.description: An ocean-mining company has funded some of the most comprehensive scientific studies to date, and peer-reviewed results have begun to emerge.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

item.title: Olivia Nuzzi and Vanity Fair Will Part Ways
item.description: Condé Nast, the magazine’s parent company, said her contract would expire at the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa

media:content.media:description: New claims about Olivia Nuzzi, who was named Vanity Fair’s West Coast editor in September, have arisen over her past relationship with Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

item.title: MAHA Activists Urge Trump to Fire Lee Zeldin at the E.P.A.
item.description: As head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Lee Zeldin has weakened protections against toxic chemicals, say members of the MAHA movement.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A petition to fire Lee Zeldin, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, had more than 2,800 signatures by midday Friday.

item.title: El precio del aguacate sigue subiendo. La culpa es de la narcoinflación
item.description: La extorsión de los cárteles está haciendo subir los precios en México, y se está convirtiendo en un problema político que la presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum no puede ignorar.
item.dc:creator: Ioan Grillo

media:content.media:description: Un árbol de aguacate en Michoacán, México, en junio de 2024. El estado, que suministra la mayoría de los aguacates destinados a Estados Unidos, ha sido escenario de un aumento de la violencia de los cárteles.

item.title: Trump amenaza con abandonar el T-MEC y pone a temblar a sus partidarios
item.description: Las audiencias que iniciaron el miércoles en Washington reflejan la inquietud sobre el futuro del pacto comercial entre Estados Unidos, México y Canadá.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

media:content.media:description: Aunque el presidente Trump negoció y firmó el Acuerdo EE. UU. -México-Canadá, este año dijo que quería convertirlo en un “acuerdo mucho mejor”.

item.title: Natalia Lafourcade: Miré atrás para encontrar mi camino
item.description: Preservar las conexiones humanas es esencial en una era digital que nos empuja hacia lo superficial.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Lafourcade

item.title: La esencia de la civilización europea se desvanece, afirma el gobierno de Trump
item.description: Estados Unidos critica políticas migratorias de varios países aliados en un documento recién publicado sobre seguridad nacional.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Jeanna Smialek and Lara Jakes

media:content.media:description: El presidente Trump no ha ocultado su desdén por el liderazgo político en Europa.

item.title: Payday Cookie Recipe for Cookie Week
item.description: Sue Li loves a Payday (bar), so she channeled its essence into her 2025 Cookie Week cookie.
item.dc:creator: Vaughn Vreeland

media:content.media:credit: Rachel Vanni for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Samantha Seneviratne. Prop Stylist: Megan Hedgpeth.
media:content.media:description: Sue Li’s peanut brown-butter cookies.

item.title: Natalia Lafourcade on Turning 40 and Recording Her New Album
item.description: Preserving tangible human connections is essential in a digital era that sweeps us toward the superficial.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Lafourcade

item.title: ‘The American Revolution’ Is Not Woke. It’s Magnificent.
item.description: Don’t be shocked: There were Black people and Native Americans during the colonial era.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Pablo Delcan; source images by Hulton Archive and Stock Montage/Getty Images
